content: Metal selenides are promising anode candidates for sodium ion batteries (SIBs) because of their high theoretical capacity, low cost, and environmental friendship. However, the low rate capability at high current density due to its inherent low electrical conductivity and poor cycle stability caused by inevitable volume variations during cycling frustrate its practical applications. Herein, we have developed a simple metallic-organic frameworks (MOFs)-derived selenide strategy to synthesize a series of heterogeneous bimetallic selenides encapsulated within graphene aerogels (GA) as anodes for SIBs. The bimetallic selenides/GA composites have unique structural characteristics that can shorten the migration path for Na+/electrons and accommodate the volume variations via additional void space during cycling. The built-in electric fields induced at the heterointerfaces can greatly reduce the activation energy for rapid charge transfer kinetics and promote the diffusion of Na+/electrons. GA is also beneficial for accommodating the volume variations during cycling and improving conductivity. As an advanced anode for SIBs, the MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA with a special porous octahedron can deliver the highest capacity of 444.8 mAh/g at a high rate of 1 A/g even after 1000 cycles among the bimetallic selenides/GA composites.
Sections.name: Abstract

content: Previous article in issue
Next article in issue
Sections.name: Graphical abstract

content: The impact of energy shortage and environmental pollution has led to an urgent need for suitable, high-performance, and viable new energy storage units for electric vehicles, equipment, and other fields to alleviate these problems [1], [2], [3]. Lithium ion batteries (LIBs) have achieved true commercial applications in a wide range of our work and daily life [4], [5]. However, the scarce lithium resources on earth and the increasing cost of LIBs hinder their long-term and widespread applications [6], [7]. In contrast, sodium behaves very rich resources and much lower cost. More importantly, sodium and lithium are the same main group elements and behave similar chemical properties. Thus, sodium ion batteries (SIBs) are one of the most suitable candidates for LIBs in some fields [8], [9], [10]. The main bottleneck in SIBs is the search for electrode materials with excellent performance, especially the anode electrode [11]. The different anode materials of SIBs, such as hard carbon [8], [9], metal oxides [12], alloys [13], sulphides [14], phosphides [15], and selenides [16], are being developed rapidly. Among these anode materials, metal selenides have become one of the most promising anodes for SIBs due to their high capacity, low cost, environmental friendliness, and rich electrochemical properties [17], [16], [18]. However, the drawbacks of its low rate capability and poor cycling stability due to its inherent poor conductivity and inevitable volume changes during cycling frustrate its practical applications [19].

To resolve these problems, some strategies have been developed to engineer the metal selenides with stable structure and excellent electrochemical properties, such as designing unique structures, coupling with carbon-based materials, selecting upper cut-off voltages, optimizing composition [20], [21], [22]. Currently, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with a specific morphological structure are usually used as precursors to design and synthesize metal selenides for the application of SIBs [23], [24], [25]. It has also been shown that the construction of metal selenide heterostructures is considered an innovative method for improving electrochemical properties [26], [27], [28]. The built-in electric fields (BIEF) existing in the heterointerfaces can reduce the activation barrier and promote reaction kinetics due to lattice distortions and electronic rearrangements [29]. The porous heterogeneous composite can not only accelerate electric charge transfer and improve the storage of sodium ions, but also avoid structural damage caused by sodium ion intercation/deintercation. Zhang et al. prepared heterojunction bimetallic selenide nanoboxes (SnSe2/CoSe2@C) with core–shell structures, exhibiting excellent sodium storage capacity [29]. Furthermore, the combination of MOF with graphene can further improve the conductivity of the active material, as well as prevent the fragmentation of the MOF during the subsequent heat treatment process and charging/discharging cycles [24]. At present, the construction of MOF-based metal selenide heterojunction/graphene composites is limited to the random combination of single MOF and graphene aerogels (GA). And there are also some uncertain factors in the regulation of heterostructure, leading to the difficulty in precise regulation of heterostructure and the improvement of performance. The synergistic effect between heterogeneous interfaces and the diffusion of Na+ ions at the phase boundary still remains to be studied. Therefore, it is a key challenge to construct the heterogeneous bimetallic selenides/GA and explore the effect factor on the electrochemcial properties.

Herein, a series of MOF-derived heterogeneous bimetallic selenides embedded within GA were successfully developed and used as anodes for SIBs. The bimetallic selenides/GA composites exhibit special structural features, such as porous octahedron, cube, and sphere, which are benefit for the efficient and rapid transport of sodium ions within the electrodes. Furthermore, the built-in electric fields induced at the heterointerfaces can also greatly reduce the reaction activation energy and promote fast reaction kinetics. Last but not the least, GA as an external carrier can not only maintain the structural integrity of the active material, but also improve the overall electronic conductivity. Benefitting from these advantages, the resulting MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA with a special porous octahedron indicates super sodium storage performance with high-capacity and fast kinetics. When used as an advanced anode for SIBs, the MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA can deliver exceptional rate capability (406.6 mAh g−1 at 2 A g−1) and high reversible capacities (533.6 mAh/g at 0.2 A/g after 100 cycles and 444.8 mAh/g at 1 A/g even after 1000 cycles). This work could provide a possible universal method for constructing a bimetallic selenide/GA composite as an advanced anode for next-generation SIBs.
Sections.name: Introduction

content: Cupric acetate (Cu2(CH3COO)4), phosphomolybdic acid hydrate (H3PO4·12MoO3·xH2O), manganese acetate tetrahydrate (Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O), potassium cyanide iridium (K3[Co(CN)6]), zinc sulfate heptahydrate (ZnSO4·7H2O), and potassium tetracyanonickelate hydrate (K3[Ni(CN)4]·xH2O) were purchased from China Pharmaceutical Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. l-glutamic acid (C5H9NO4, 99.9 %), trimesic acid (C9H6O6, 99.9 %), polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, K-30, 99.9 %), and selenium (Se, 99.9 %) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. All chemicals and solvents were used directly without further purification.
content.name: Materials

content: Preparation of Mo-Cu-MOF: Typically, 0.1996 g of cupric acetate, 0.0735 g of l-glutamic acid and 0.3686 g of phosphomolybdic acid hydrate were added into 40 mL of water to form solution A. 0.138 g of trimesic acid was added into 40 mL of ethanol to form solution B. Then, solution B was dropped into solution A at a speed of 5 mL min−1 using a peristaltic pump under continuous stirring for 24 h at room temperature. The precipitate was centrifuged, washed three times by distilled water and ethanol, and was then dried in a vacuum oven to obtain the Mo-Cu-MOF precursor.

Preparation of Co-Mn-MOF: Typically, 0.276 g of Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O and 1 g of polyvinylpyrrolidone were added into 60 mL of ethanol to produce solution A, and 0.1995 g of K3[Co(CN)6] was added into 60 mL of water to produce solution B. Solution B was dropped into solution A at a speed of 5 mL min−1 using a peristaltic pump under continuous stirring for 24 h at room temperature. The precipitate was then centrifuged, washed three times with distilled water and ethanol, and dried in a vacuum oven to obtain the Co-Mn-MOF precursor.

Preparation of Ni-Zn-MOF: Typically, 0.24 g of ZnSO4·7H2O and 0.45 g of polyvinylpyrrolidone were dispersed in 50 mL of water to form a clear solution. Separately, 0.2 g of K3[Ni(CN)4]·xH2O was dissolved in 50 mL of water under magnetic stirring to form another clear solution. Subsequently, the two solution were combined to form a suspension, which was magnetically stirred for 24 h at room temperature. After that, a precipitate was centrifuged, washed with distilled water and ethanol for three times, and then dried in a vacuum oven at 80 °C to obtain the Ni-Zn-MOF precursor.

Preparation of MoSe2-Cu1.8Se@GA: Graphene oxide (GO) was obtained using an improved Hummers method [30]. 0.2 g of Mo-Cu-MOF was added into an aqueous dispersion of graphene oxide (GO) (1.5 mg mL−1, 30 mL) with vigorous stirring to form Mo-Cu-MOF@GO composite for 24 h at room temperature. Then, the composite was further freeze-dried overnight to obtain Mo-Cu-MOF@GO aerogel. 0.2 g of Mo-Cu-MOF@GO aerogel was mixed with 0.4 g of Se powder and kept at 450 °C for 2 h with a ramp rate of 2 °C·min−1 in 5 % H2/Ar atmosphere to get MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@graphene aerogel (MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA). In the same way, CoSe2-MnSe@GA and NiSe2-ZnSe@GA were obtained under similar conditions.
content.name: Sample preparations

content: X-ray diffractometry (XRD) data of the as-obtained products were collected on a Shimadzu 6000 diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromatized CuKα radiation flux. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was measured by scanning electron microscope (Carl Zeiss Supra 40). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-resolution TEM (HRTEM), and energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) mapping analysis were taken with JEM-2100 (JEOL Co., Japan) microscope. The surface composition and the valence state of the products were performed by Thermo ESCALAB 250XI. Raman spectra were measured by a Renishaw InVia instrument with a He-Ne laser (532 nm) excitation source at a resolution of 1 cm−1.
content.name: Material characterizations

content: Electrochemical measurements of the as-synthesized samples were performed using CR2032 half-cells with Na sheet as counter electrode and Whatman GF/D as separator. The active materials were mixed with Super P and PVDF at a mass ratio of 70:20:10 and ground into a slurry with 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP). The slurry was then poured onto the copper foil and dried in a vacuum oven at 70 °C for 12 h. The area mass was loaded at approximately 1.2 mg cm−2. The electrolyte for the CR2032 half-cells was 1 M NaPF6 in dimethyl ether. Cell assembly was performed in an argon filled glove box (O2 < 0.1 ppm, H2O < 0.1 ppm). Electrostatic charge/discharge tests were performed using a LAND CT-2001A battery tester at various current densities within a cut-off voltage range of 0.01–3.0 V (vs. Na+/Na). Cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements were performed on an electrochemical workstation (CHI 760 E, Chenhua Ltd. Co., China) with a scan speed of 0.2 mV s−1, and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) tests were obtained using an electrochemical workstation (Autolab PGSTAT 302 N) with an amplitude of 5 mV and a frequency range of 100 kHz to 0.1 Hz.
content.name: Electrochemical measurements

content: Scheme 1 illustrates the fabrication process of the heterogeneous bimetallic selenides encapsulated within GA. The morphologies and microstructures of the as-obtained products were investigated by SEM and TEM. As seen in Fig. 1a, the Mo-Cu-MOF precursor reveals a smooth octahedral structure with a diameter of 1 μm or so. Fig. 1b shows the SEM image of the Mo-Cu-MOF@GO aerogel. It can be found that the Mo-Cu-MOF still retains original octahedral structure after wrapping with GO. The SEM image of Fig. 1c clearly confirms the existence of GA and MoSe2-Cu1.82Se with the diameter of 900 nm or so, which is smaller than that of the Mo-Cu-MOF precursor. It is interesting that during the selenization process some octahedra are converted into small nanoparticles to form secondary nanomaterials. It is more beneficial to increase the contact areas between the active material and electrolyte, and shorten the transport channel of Na+, thereby resulting in the improvement of sodium storage performance. Fig. 1d exhibits the SEM images of Co-Mn-MOF precursor. It can be obviously seen that the Co-Mn-MOF consists of cubic particles with a diameter of 1 μm or so, which is different from the Mo-Cu-MOF. The Co-Mn-MOF are further combined with GO to obtain Co-Mn-MOF@GO (Fig. 1e). Fig. 1f displays the SEM images of CoSe2-MnSe@GA, clearly showing the homogeneous shape of the cubes with a diameter of 900 nm or so wrapped with GA. While the Ni-Zn-MOF precursor behaves as uniform microspheres with a diameter of about 500 nm. The Ni-Zn-MOF@GO also shows a homogeneous spherical shape wrapped among GO (Fig. 1h). Close observation of the morphology by high magnification SEM reveals that the NiSe2-ZnSe microspheres are all uniformly wrapped within a layer of graphene, and that high-temperature selenisation does not produce morphological fragments (Fig. 1i). The aerogel networks formed by GA can effectively avoid the powder agglomeration and volume expansion during the high temperature selenisation process. The addition of GA is sure help to synthesize the heterogeneous bimetallic selenide composite.

The structural features of the bimetallic selenide@GA composites were further investigated by TEM and HRTEM. Fig. 2a exhibits the TEM images of MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA with the diameter of 900 nm or so, which is consistent with the SEM images. It can be clearly seen that the rough octahedral structure is surrounded by thin layers of graphene sheets. As shown in Fig. 2b, an interplanar crystal spacing of 0.20 nm correlates to the crystal plane of Cu1.82Se, and another interplanar crystal spacing of 0.19 nm corresponds to the crystal plane of MoSe2. From the HRTEM of MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA, it can be also seen that there are apparent heterogeneous interfaces between MoSe2 and Cu1.82Se. The heterogeneous interfaces can cause uneven charge distribution on different crystal faces and form potential difference, thus inducing built-in electric fields. The built-in electric fields can reduce the activation energy, accelerate the transfer of sodium ions, and promote Na+/electrons separation and diffusion, resulting in the improvement of sodium ion storage during the charge/discharge process [29]. It is interesting that the distinct boundary between MoSe2-Cu1.82Se and GA could be also found in the HRTEM images of Fig. 2b, helping to the improvement of electrochemical properties. In the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) image presented in Fig. 2c, the diffraction rings of MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA correspond to (0 2 2) lattice planes of Cu1.8Se and (0 2 6), (3 1 1) lattice planes of MoSe2, respectively. For the CoSe2-MnSe@GA (Fig. 2d), the CoSe2-MnSe cubic particles with the diameter of 900 nm or so are embedded between graphene sheets, which is similar to the SEM results (Fig. 1i). Fig. 2e exhibits the TEM images of NiSe2-ZnSe@GA. It is obviously seen that the NiSe2-ZnSe@GA microspheres are also wrapped within graphene sheets. The clear visibility of the atomic stripes in the HRTEM image strongly suggests that the NiSe2-ZnSe@GA is highly crystalline (Fig. 2f). The atomic lattice stripe with a distance of 0.31 nm corresponds to (0 1 1) plane of cubic NiSe2, while the lattice spacing of 0.20 nm is represented by the (2 2 0) plane of ZnSe. It should be noted that there are also bimetallic heterogeneous interfaces in the NiSe2-ZnSe@GA which can generate built-in electric fields [29]. Fig. 2g shows the EDX mapping images of MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA. The elemental mapping photos show the homogeneous distributions of C, Mo, Se, and Cu elements in the MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA hybrid.

The XRD patterns of the MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA are shown in Fig. 3a, which clearly reveals the combination of MoSe2 (JCPDS card no. 04-005-6604), Cu1.82Se (JCPDS card no. 04-002-6190), and GA. Specifically, the characteristic peaks of 31.3°, 37.8°, 47.4°, 53.2° and 55.8° correspond to the (1 0 0), (1 0 3), (1 0 5), (1 0 6) and (1 1 0) crystal face of MoSe2, while the peak at 44.7° represents the crystal face (2 2 0) of Cu1.82Se. The Raman spectrum of MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA is exhibited in Fig. 3b. The intensity ratio of ID/IG can be used to determine the degree of graphitization of carbon materials. The MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA exhibits a peak intensity ratio (ID/IG) of 0.7 or so, indicating its lower graphitization degree. The XPS survey spectrum confirms that the elements of Mo, Cu, Se, C, and O are present in the MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA (Fig. 3c). Fig. 3d displays the XPS spectrum of Mo3d with two obvious peaks at 232.2 eV and 229.9 eV, which are ascribed to Mo 3d3/2 and Mo 3d5/2, respectively [31]. The narrow peaks at 952.7 eV and 933.8 eV can be detected from the Cu2p XPS spectrum (Fig. 3e), which correspond to the signals of Cu 2p1/2 and Cu 2p3/2, respectively. Furthermore, two shake-up satellite peaks can also be observed at 934.6 and 943.1 eV of Cu 2p [32]. According to Fig. 3f, the peaks in the Se 3d spectrum located at 55.1 and 54.4 eV are attributed to the Se 3d3/2 and Se 3d5/2 binding energies, whereas the signal at 59.3 eV corresponds to the Se-O binding energy [33]. The XRD patterns of CoSe2-MnSe@GA are consistent with the standard JCPDS card No. 03-065-3327 for CoSe2 and JCPDS card 04-004-6054 for MnSe (Fig. S1a). In addition, the Raman spectrum of CoSe2-MnSe@GA shows an intensity ratio (ID/IG) of around 0.83, which is slightly higher than that of MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA (Fig. S1b). Fig. S1c–f exhibit the XPS spectrum of CoSe2-MnSe@GA. Based on the XPS survey spectrum, it is evident that the Mn, Co, Se, O, and C are present (Fig. S1c). As seen in Fig. S1d, the Co 2p spectrum shows five peaks. The peaks located at 781.3 and 797.5 eV are ascribed to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2, respectively, implying the presence of Co2+ in CoSe2-MnSe@GA [34]. In contrast, the peaks at 778.8 and 793.2 eV correspond to Co 2p3/2 and 2p1/2, respectively [35]. And the peaks at 654.0 and 641.8 eV are ascribed to Mn 2p1/2 and Mn 2p3/2, respectively (Fig. S1e) [34], [36]. Fig. S1f shows three peaks at 55.7, 56.6, and 59.5 eV, corresponding to Se 3d5/2, Se 3d3/2, and SeOx, respectively [37], [38]. The XRD pattern of NiSe2-ZnSe@GA clearly shows a good match to NiSe2 (JCPDS card 04-003-4305) and ZnSe (JCPDS card 04-001-7280) (Fig. S2a). The Raman spectrum of NiSe2-ZnSe@GA behaves an intensity ratio (ID/IG) of 0.72 (Fig. S2b). Fig. S2c–f exhibit the NiSe2-ZnSe@GA XPS pattern. Spectrum analysis of Zn 2p at high resolution confirms the presence of Zn 2p3/2 at 1022.4 eV and Zn 2p1/2 at 1045.4 eV (Fig. S2d) [39]. The Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 are responsible for the peaks at 855.5 and 873.6 eV, and the satellite peaks are responsible for two other weak peaks (Fig. S2e) [40]. The peaks at 55.1 and 56.1 eV reflect the presence of Se 3d5/2 and 3d3/2, respectively, and the board peak at 58.9 eV indicates its high oxide state (Fig. S2f) [41]. These above characterizations, including SEM, TEM, EDX, XRD, Raman and XPS, further demonstrate that the heterogeneous bimetallic selenides are well encapsulated within GA.

Fig. 4a shows the first three CV profiles of MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA. It is confirmed that the reduction peaks at 0.39 and 0.72 V are caused by the decomposition of the electrolyte and the production of a solid electrolyte interface (SEI) film, which subsequently disappear in subsequent cycles, whereas all other reduction peaks are determined as the insertion of Na+ [42]. NaCuSe is transformed to NaxCuSe at 1.63 V, and the subsequent desodiation from NaxCuSe results in an anodic peak at 1.93 V [32], [43]. During the formation of NaxMoSe2, the peak at 0.67 V is observed [44]. Specifically, the peak located at 1.22 V is attributed to the conversion reaction between MoSe2 and Na+ that produces Mo and Na2Se [45]. The intercalation of Na+ into Cu1.82Se and MoSe2 results in the cathodic peaks at 1.51, 1.75 and 2.05 V [35], [46]. The above proposed sodium storage mechanism of MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA could be concluded as follows (Eqs. 1–9) [45], [47], [48]:
The discharge reaction:(1)
C u 1.82 S e + x N a + + e - → N a x C u S e + 0.82 C u(2)
N a x C u S e + 1 - x N a + + 1 - x e - → N a C u S e(3)
N a C u S e + N a + + e - → C u + N a 2 S e(4)
M o S e 2 + x N a + + e - → N a x M o S e 2(5)
N a x M o S e 2 + N a + + e - → M o + N a 2 S eThe charge reaction:(6)
C u + N a 2 S e → N a C u S e + N a + + e -(7)
N a C u S e + C u → C u 1.82 S e + N a + + e -(8)
M o + N a 2 S e → N a x M o S e 2 + N a + + x e -(9)
N a x M o S e 2 → M o S e 2 + N a + + e -

Fig. 4b exhibits the charge–discharge curves of MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA with obvious discharge platforms at 1.94, 1.0, 0.71, 0.38 V and charge platforms at 1.51, 1.73, 2.08 V, which are well consistent with the CV curves. The initial discharge/charge capacities of MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA are 672.4/503.9 mAh/g with an initial coulombic efficiency (ICE) of 75.6 %, which is higher than some previous reports [42], [46]. A clear upward trend is evident in the cycling stability of MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA with a specific capacity of 533.6 mAh/g after 100 cycles at 0.2 A/g, illustrating its excellent cycle stability (Fig. 4c). The MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA delivers average discharge capacities of 426.3, 423.1, 416.1, 409.5, 406.6 mAh/g at the different current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, and 2 A/g, respectively (Fig. 4d). It is interesting that the specific capacity of 427.1 mAh/g can be obtained when the rate is returned back to 0.2 A/g. Moreover, the specific capacity at low rates of 0.1 and 0.2 A/g is nearly equal to the high rate of 2 A/g. All these results demonstrate the excellent rate capability of the MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA electrode. Fig. 4e displays the cycling performance of the MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA electrode at the high rate of 1 A/g. It can be seen that the specific capacity of the MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA remains around 444.8 mAh/g even after 1000 cycles at 1 A/g, further confirming its excellent sodium storage capability. It should be noted that the MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA electrode also exhibited the outstanding sodium storage performance compared to other previous reports (Table S1) [43], [44], [45], [46], [47], [48], [49]. The superior sodium storage capability could attribute to the bimetallic selenide heterostructure which improve the reaction kinetic and promote sodium ions diffusion [29]. In addition, the synergistic effect between unique structure (porous octahedron), and GA was beneficial for alleviate volume expansion and prevent rapid capacity decay [17].

We further investigated the capacitive behaviors of the MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA by the CV measurement at different scan rates. As shown in Fig. 4f, the CV profiles display similar shapes at different scan rates from 0.2 mV s−1 to 1.0 mV s−1. The mean b-value for the reduction–oxidation peaks was calculated to be 0.88, indicating a pseudocapacitive effect and fast kinetics (Fig. 4g) (Text S1) [49], [50]. The light green area shows the contribution of the pseudocapacitive behavior with a calculated ratio of 74.5 % at a sweep rate of 0.6 mV s−1 (Fig. 4h). The pseudocapacitive contributions are 56.69 %, 57.89 %, 74.51 %, 83.56 %, and 88.71 % at different scan rates (Fig. 4i). With the increase of scan rates, the pseudocapacitive contribution gradually increases, demonstrating the rapid kinetics of the MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA at high current density. Based on these results, it is clear that the pseudocapacitive charge storage occupies a high percentage of the total capacity.

Fig. 5a shows the CV curves for CoSe2-MnSe@GA with some obvious irreversible peaks at 0.19, 0.34, and 1.04 V associated with SEI films [51]. NaxMnSe is formed and then converted to Na2Se and Mn, resulting in two peaks at 1.50 and 0.72 V, respectively [52]. Additionally, the reduction peak at 1.50 V is related to the insertion of CoSe2 with Na+ [45]. For the anodic scan, the two oxidation peaks at 1.50 and 1.84 V are caused by the desodification process and the formation of CoSe2, respectively [51], [53]. In addition, a weak peak at 2.04 V is assigned to the formation of MnSe [46], [54]. The CV curves of CoSe2-MnSe@GA overlapped well in subsequent discharge–charge cycles, indicating its good stabilization as anodes for SIBs. The chemical reactions of CoSe2-MnSe@GA are summarized as follows (Equs. 10–18):
The discharge reaction:(10)
M n S e + x N a + + e - → N a x M n S e(11)
N a x M n S e + 2 - x N a + + ( 2 - x ) e - → M n + N a 2 S e(12)
C o S e 2 + x N a + + x e - → N a x C o S e 2(13)
N a x C o S e 2+ 2 - x N a + + 2 - x e - → C o S e + N a 2 S e(14)
C o S e+ 2 N a + + 2 e - → C o + N a 2 S eThe charge reaction:(15)
M n + N a 2 S e → N a x M n S e + 2 - x N a + + 2 - x e -(16)
N a x M n S e + C u → M n S e + x N a + + x e -(17)
C o + 2 N a 2 S e → N a x C o S e 2 + 4 - x N a + + 4 - x e -(18)

N a x C o S e 2 → C o S e 2 + x N a + + x e -Fig. 5b exhibits the charge/discharge curves of CoSe2-MnSe@GA, corresponding to the plateau of the CV curves. In Fig. 5c, the specific capacity delivered by CoSe2-MnSe@GA is about 456.7 mAh/g at 0.2 A/g after 100 cycles, which is slightly lower than that of MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA. The CoSe2-MnSe@GA delivers a specific capacity of 470.6, 457.1, 439.9, 425.4, 406.6, 460.9 mAh/g at different current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, 0.2 A/g, respectively (Fig. 5d). And the specific capacity of the CoSe2-MnSe@GA electrode remains at 442.9 mAh/g at 1 A/g after 1000 cycles (Fig. 5e). A similar pseudocapacitive test was carried out for CoSe2-MnSe@GA and the calculated b-value was approximately 0.87 (Fig. 5f and g, Text S1). And the corresponding capacitive contributions are 54.57 %, 56.47 %, 73.54 %, 82.35 %, and 88.03 % at the scan rates of 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, and 1 mV s−1, respectively, belonging to the pseudocapacitive contribution (Fig. 5h and i). It is interesting that the CoSe2-MnSe@GA electrode also exhibits outstanding sodium storage compared to other previous reports (Table S1).

The first four CV curves for NiSe2-ZnSe@GA are also exhibited in Fig. 6a. The first CV cycle is inconsistent with the subsequent three cycles, which might be related to the decomposition of the electrolyte and the formation of the SEI film. In the initial cycle, two irreversible peaks occur at around 0.33 V and 1.27 V, which could be ascribed to the generation of the SEI layer and the disposable sodium storage point [55]. The additional reduction peaks are all associated with the insertion of Na+ and the production of Na2Se, Zn, and Ni [56], [57]. In contrast, the generation of oxidation peaks corresponds to the removal of Na+ [58], [59]. The first discharge/charge capacity of the NiSe2-ZnSe@GA is 736.8/491.9 mAh/g with an initial coulombic efficiency of 66.8 %. After 50th cycle, the discharge/charge capacity is 242.1/236.8 mAh/g with the coulombic efficiency of 97.8 %. Fig. 6c exhibits the cycling performance of NiSe2-ZnSe@GA at 0.2 A/g, where a specific capacity of 302.2 mAh/g could be obtained after 100 cycles. The NiSe2-ZnSe@GA delivers specific capacities of 285.8, 237.7, 206.0, 180.1, 171.1, 203.1 mAh/g at different current densities from 0.1 to 2.0 A/g, respectively (Fig. 6d). While the NiSe2-ZnSe@GA only deliver a specific capacity of 190.5 mAh/g at a high current of 1 A/g after 1000 cycles, which is much lower than that of the MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA and CoSe2-MnSe@GA (Fig. 6e). The average b-value of the six redox peaks for the NiSe2-ZnSe@GA is about 0.58 (Fig. 6f and g), being different from MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA and CoSe2-MnSe@GA. The capacitive contributions are 48.78 %, 52.03 %, 69.39 %, 79.07 %, and 85.48 % at the different scan rates of 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, and 1 mV s−1, respectively (Fig. 6h and i). It was found that the NiSe2-ZnSe@GA electrode exhibits a lower pseudocapacitance contribution compared to the other two samples, indicating a slower transport rate and kinetic response. To further investigate the good cycling performances of the active materials, we further characterized the thickness of the electrode sheet (Fig. S3). Fig. S3a–f show the thickness of the electrode sheets before and after cycling. It can be noticed that the electrode sheets all have undergone different degrees of expansion. The expansion thickness of MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA (2.5 μm) and CoSe2-MnSe@GA (3.8 μm) is much lower than that of NiSe2-ZnSe@GA (9.7 μm), confirming the excellent electrochemical properties of MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA and CoSe2-MnSe@GA.

Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were used to analyze the kinetic differences between the different electrodes. All Nyquist plots in Fig. S4a exhibit a depressed semicircle and a descending line in the high and low frequency regions, corresponding to the charge transfer resistance (Rct) and Warburg impedance (Wo), respectively [60], [61], [62]. Fig. S4b shows the Randall-type equivalent circuit model, and the results are presented in Tab. S2. The Nyquist plots show that the impedance of these samples is in a clear sequence of MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA < CoSe2-MnSe@GA < NiSe2-ZnSe@GA, corresponding to the Rct of 6.23, 33.55, and 40.33 Ω, respectively. Electrical impedance measurements further demonstrate that the highest capacity of MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA with a special porous octahedron is related to its lower impedance and rapid reaction kinetics. This result is also consistent with the excellent rate capability of MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA since the charge transfer process is the rate-determining step for sodium ion storage.
Sections.name: Results and discussion

content: In summary, we have developed three types of heterogeneous bimetallic selenides encapsulated within GA via a simple MOF-derived selenide strategy. The bimetallic selenides/GA composites exhibit special structural features, such as porous octahedron, cubes, or spheres, which can shorten the migration path for Na+/electrons and accommodate the volume variations of the metal selenides via additional void space during cycling. GA can not only keep the structural integrity of the active material during cycling, but also improve the conductivity of the electrode, resulting in the enhancement electrochemical property. The built-in electric fields at the heterointerfaces can enhance reaction kinetics and promote the diffusion of Na+/electrons. As an advanced anode for SIBs, the MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA with a porous octahedron delivers the highest capacity of 444.8 mAh/g at a high current rate of 1 A/g after 1000 cycles. It should be noted that the MoSe2-Cu1.82Se@GA electrode also exhibits outstanding sodium storage and cycle performances, even compared to other previous reports [43], [44], [45], [46], [47], [48], [49]. This work could provide a possible universal method for constructing a bimetallic selenide/GA with homogeneous microstructure as anodes for the next-generation SIBs.
Sections.name: Conclusions

Kun Liu: Software, Formal analysis. Dong Wang: Software, Methodology, Data curation. Lulin Ren: Validation, Software. Yumeng Wei: Visualization, Methodology. Lizhuang Chen: Investigation, Formal analysis. Yingying Chen: Validation, Methodology. Shanhu Liu: Software, Resources, Formal analysis. Hongxun Yang: .

Title: Regular ArticleHeterogeneous bimetallic selenides encapsulated within graphene aerogel as advanced anodes for sodium ion batteries
